name: Rita Lee
description:
'''Rita Lee Jones de Carvalho''' (born '''Rita Lee Jones'''; 31 December 1947 – 8 May 2023), known as '''Rita Lee''',{{efn|{{IPA|pt-BR|ˈʁi.tɐ ˈli}} {{respell|HEE|tah|LEE}}}} was a Brazilian singer, songwriter, television presenter, actress, writer, and activist. Known as the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Queen of Brazilian Rock]]", she surpassed 55 million records sold, making her the [[List of best-selling music artists in Brazil#Best-selling Brazilian artists worldwide|second best-selling female artist in Brazil]]—behind only [[Angela Maria]]—and the fourth overall. She built a career that began with [[Rock music|rock]] but, over the years, explored various genres, including [[psychedelia]], [[pop rock]], [[disco]], [[New wave music|new wave]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[bossa nova]], and [[electronic music]], creating a pioneering hybrid of international and national styles.

Rita was considered one of Brazil's most influential musicians, serving as a reference for those who began using [[Electric guitar|guitar]] from the mid-1970s onward. A former member of the group [[Os Mutantes]] (1966–1972) and [[Tutti Frutti (Brazilian band)|Tutti Frutti]] (1973–1978), she participated in significant revolutions in music and society. Her songs, often laced with biting irony or advocating female independence, became ubiquitous on the charts. Among the most popular are "Ovelha Negra", "Mania de Você", "Lança Perfume", "Agora Só Falta Você", "Baila Comigo", "Banho de Espuma", "Desculpe o Auê", "Erva Venenosa", "Amor e Sexo", "Flagra", and "Doce Vampiro". The album ''[[Fruto Proibido]]'' (1975), released with Tutti Frutti, is widely regarded as a fundamental milestone in [[Music of Brazil#Brazilian rock|Brazilian rock]] history, ranked among the [[List of Rolling Stone Brasil 100 Greatest Brazilian Music Records|100 greatest albums in Brazilian music history]] by ''Rolling Stone Brasil'', while the [[Rolling Stone|U.S. edition]] of the magazine included it among the best in Latin American rock.

In 1976, she began a romantic relationship with multi-instrumentalist and composer Roberto de Carvalho, who became her partner on most compositions. During this period, she released a series of albums—such as ''[[Rita Lee (album)|Rita Lee]]'' (1979), ''Rita Lee'' (1980), ''Saúde'' (1981), and ''Rita Lee e Roberto de Carvalho'' (1982)—that achieved massive sales success and solidified her popularity. The couple had three children, including guitarist [[Beto Lee]], who accompanied his parents on stage. Rita was a [[Veganism|vegan]] and advocate for [[animal rights]], [[women's rights]], and the [[LGBTQ rights by country or territory|LGBT community]]. With a sixty-year career, the artist transitioned from the innovation and musical underground of the 1960s and 1970s to highly successful romantic ballads in the 1980s—participating in a true musical revolution and performing alongside artists such as [[Elis Regina]], [[João Gilberto]], and the band [[Titãs]]. In October 2008, ''Rolling Stone'' published its list of the 100 greatest Brazilian music artists, where she ranked 15th. In 2023, Rita, who had been diagnosed with [[lung cancer]] two years earlier, died at age 75 on May 8.
